fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. The functor \mathbb P_X : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C given by \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y can be given the structure of a commutative comonad, called the parameters comonad, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The counit \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y \to Y is given by the projection
The comultiplication \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y \to X \times X \times Y = \mathbb P_X^2 (Y) is given by the diagonal
The commutative strength \mathbb P_X (Y) \times Z = (X \times Y) \times Z \to X \times (Y \times Z) = \mathbb P_X (Y \times Z) is the natural isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given a morphism X \to X' of \mathcal C, the natural transformation f \times : X \times - \to X' \times - extends to a morphism of comonads f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y.

fr:title.text: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products. A morphism f : X \to X' of \mathcal C induces a functor f^* : \mathcal C \setminus X' \to \mathcal C \setminus X where:

html:ul.html:li:
For a morphism g : X' \times Y \to Z, f^* (g) : X \times Y \to Z is given by
X \times Y \overset {f \times Y}\longrightarrow X' \times Y \overset {g}\longrightarrow Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This yields an indexed category \mathcal C \setminus - : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat}.

This structure can also be seen as arising from the comonad morphisms f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y between the parameters comonads, since morphisms of comonads lift contravariantly to functors between Kleisli categories.
Since f^* is identity on objects, it also preserves products in simple slice categories. Thus \mathcal C \setminus - : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} has indexed finite products.

Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. We write \mathcal C \setminus X for the Kleisli category of the parameters comonad \mathbb P_X : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C.
Concretely, \mathcal C \setminus X is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \mathcal C \setminus X are objects of \mathcal C
Morphisms f : Y \to Z in \mathcal C \setminus X are morphisms f : X \times Y \to Z in \mathcal C
The identity morphism Y \to Y in \mathcal C \setminus X is the projection X \times Y \to Y in \mathcal C

The composition of f : X \times Y \to Z and g : X \times Z \to W is given by
X \times Y \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \times Y \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Z \overset {g}\longrightarrow W

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Reference: Categorical logic and type theory

fr:title.text: Products in the simple slice category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products in the simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. Then the simple slice category \mathcal C \setminus X has finite products, given by the underlying products in \mathcal C.
To prove this, we construct the Kleisli adjunction between \mathcal C and \mathcal C \setminus X.
The left adjoint L : \mathcal C \setminus X \to \mathcal C is given by:

html:ul.html:li: f : X \times Y \to Z is taken to L (f) : X \times Y \to X \times Z given by the pairing of the projection and f

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The right adjoint R : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C \setminus X is given by:

html:ul.html:li: f : Y \to Z is taken to R (f) : X \times Y \to Z given by precomposition with the projection

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
The hom-set isomorphism is proven as follows:
\mathcal C (L (Y), Z) = \mathcal C (X \times Y, Z) = (\mathcal C \setminus X) (Y, Z) = (\mathcal C \setminus X) (Y, R (Z))

Since R is a right adjoint it preserves limits. Since \mathcal C \setminus X has the same objects as \mathcal C and since R is identity on objects, this establishes that \mathcal C \setminus X has finite products given by finite products in \mathcal C.
Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and X an object of \mathcal C. Recall that the simple slice category \mathcal C \setminus X has finite products.
We can universally characterise \mathcal C as the smallest category with finite products that contains \mathcal C and another morphism x : 1 \to X.
Based on the analogous construction of polynomial rings, the simple slice \mathcal C \setminus X is sometimes called a polynomial category and denoted \mathcal C [x].
Reference: Lambek & Scott, Introduction to higher-order categorical logic
